commander.name: Major-General Raymond Briggs
commander.notes: Commanded division through El Alamein and entire Tunisia Campaign until May 1943. Promoted to acting major-general 21 August 1942.

command.headquarters_location: Tunisia (mobile - El Kourzia area April, near Tunis May 1943)

M4 Sherman II/III.notes: Primary battle tank - 2nd Armoured Brigade equipped predominantly with Shermans by Tunisia Campaign

M3 Grant.notes: Largely replaced by Shermans, small numbers retained for support roles

Crusader III.notes: Remaining in reconnaissance and close support roles

M3 Stuart 'Honey'.notes: Reconnaissance role with 12th Royal Lancers (Armoured Reconnaissance Regiment)

tanks.notes: Tank establishment reorganized April 1943 to 186 tanks per armoured division (down from previous 246). Division had 1 Grant, 92 Shermans, and 68 Crusaders at El Alamein (October 1942), transitioned to Sherman-dominated force by Tunisia Campaign.

Ordnance QF 25-pounder.notes: Two field regiments RHA: 2nd Regiment RHA (24 guns), 4th Regiment RHA (24 guns)

Ordnance QF 6-pounder.notes: 76th Anti-Tank Regiment RA - standard divisional AT establishment for 1943

Ordnance QF 17-pounder.notes: Limited numbers of new 17-pdr beginning to appear in Tunisia Campaign

Ordnance ML 3-inch Mortar.notes: Infantry battalion heavy weapons - 7th Motor Brigade battalions

supply_logistics.supply_status: GOOD - First Army supply lines from Algerian ports (Algiers, Bone) well established by April 1943. Division advanced from Libya through southern Tunisia, supplied via First Army logistics network after joining IX Corps on April 15. Final offensive (May 1-13) well supplied despite increasing Axis supply collapse. Post-battle (May 13 onward) excellent supply situation.

weather_environment.season_quarter: 1943-Q2 (April-June) - Spring transitioning to early summer in Tunisia
weather_environment.terrain_type: Northern Tunisia: Mixed terrain - coastal plains, hills, agricultural valleys. Division fought at Wadi Akarit (April 6-7), El Kourzia hills (April 22-26), final advance to Tunis through mixed terrain (May 8-13). Post-battle: Tunisia garrison/coastal areas.

subordinate_units.notes: Three armoured regiments plus one motor battalion (9th Bn KOYLI). Primary striking force of division. Equipped predominantly with Sherman tanks by Tunisia Campaign.
Part of 2nd Armoured Brigade. Sherman-equipped regiment.
Part of 2nd Armoured Brigade. Sherman-equipped regiment.
Part of 2nd Armoured Brigade. Sherman-equipped regiment.

subordinate_units.unit_designation: 9th Battalion, King's Own Yorkshire Light Infantry
subordinate_units.notes: Joined 2nd Armoured Brigade 19 December 1942, replacing Queen's Own Yorkshire Dragoons. Motorized infantry support for armoured brigade.
Three motor battalions. Provided infantry component of armoured division under April 1943 reorganization.
Part of 7th Motor Brigade. Joined 15 January 1943.
Divisional reconnaissance regiment. Equipped with Stuart light tanks and armoured cars. April 1943 reorganization replaced armoured car regiment with armoured reconnaissance regiment.
24x Ordnance QF 25-pounder guns. Self-propelled and towed variants.
24x Ordnance QF 25-pounder guns. Self-propelled and towed variants.
Self-propelled 25-pounder regiment (Priest or Bishop SP guns). Note: April 1943 reorganization reduced field regiments from 3 to 2, but division retained 3 regiments during Tunisia.
48x 6-pounder AT guns, with limited numbers of new 17-pounder guns appearing
Divisional engineers - mine clearance, bridging, obstacle construction
Engineering stores and heavy equipment support
Division-level communications. Royal Corps of Signals.

tactical_doctrine.role: Mobile armoured warfare - breakthrough and exploitation operations in Tunisia Campaign. Division transitioned from Eighth Army (pursuit from Libya) to First Army (northern Tunisia offensive) in April 1943.
special_capabilities: Combined arms armoured warfare (armoured brigade + motor brigade coordination)
Coordinated artillery support with three field regiments
Experienced in desert warfare (El Alamein veterans)
tactical_innovations: Sherman tanks providing improved firepower and reliability over previous Crusader/Grant mix
Reorganized brigade structure (one armoured brigade, one motor brigade) per April 1943 War Office directive
Armoured reconnaissance regiment replacing armoured car regiment (increased combat capability)
known_issues: Transitioning organizational structure during campaign (April 1943 reorganization implemented mid-campaign)
Mixed tank types still present (Shermans, Grants, Crusaders) though Sherman-dominated
Long approach march from Libya through southern Tunisia before joining First Army operations
Coordination challenges when transitioning from Eighth Army to First Army command
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Division highly experienced in North Africa desert warfare (Operation Crusader, Gazala, El Alamein). Tunisia operations involved transition to more varied terrain including hills, agricultural land, and coastal areas.

operations.name: Advance into Tunisia from Libya
operations.role: Division advanced from Libya with Eighth Army, entering Tunisia under X Corps command on March 13, 1943
operations.outcome: Successfully entered Tunisia, linked up with First Army forces

operations.name: Tebaga Gap
operations.role: Participated in Eighth Army flanking operation around Mareth Line defenses
operations.outcome: Contributed to forcing Axis withdrawal from Mareth Line

operations.name: Battle of Wadi Akarit
operations.role: Division attacked Axis defensive positions at Wadi Akarit under X Corps, Eighth Army. Final action before transfer to First Army.
operations.outcome: Successful breakthrough, forced Axis withdrawal northward. Division performed well in coordinated assault.

operations.name: Transfer to First Army
operations.role: Division transferred from X Corps (Eighth Army) to IX Corps (First Army) for final offensive in northern Tunisia
operations.outcome: Smooth transition, division integrated into First Army operations

operations.name: Battle of El Kourzia
operations.role: Division assaulted heavily defended hill positions at El Kourzia as part of Operation Vulcan. IX Corps, First Army. Challenging terrain for armoured operations.
operations.outcome: Captured El Kourzia positions after intense fighting. Demonstrated division's capability in difficult hill terrain despite being optimized for mobile warfare.

operations.name: Final Offensive to Tunis
operations.role: Division placed in First Army Reserve on May 1, rejoined IX Corps on May 8 for final advance. Participated in closing actions near Tunis as Axis forces collapsed.
operations.outcome: Axis forces surrendered May 13, 1943. Tunisia Campaign concluded. Over 250,000 Axis troops captured.

operations.name: Post-Campaign Reorganization
operations.role: Division left IX Corps on May 22, transferred back to Eighth Army command, moved to Libya briefly before returning to Tunisia for rest and refitting
operations.outcome: Division prepared for future operations (eventually deployed to Italy in 1944)

historical_context.combat_effectiveness: EXCELLENT - Division performed very well throughout Tunisia Campaign despite challenging operational transitions. Successfully fought at Wadi Akarit (April 6-7), adapted to difficult hill terrain at El Kourzia (April 22-26), and contributed to final Axis collapse. Division demonstrated high combat effectiveness built on experience from Crusader, Gazala, and El Alamein campaigns. Commander Raymond Briggs provided continuity from El Alamein through Tunisia. Sherman tanks proved highly effective, superior to earlier Crusader/Grant mix.

scenario_suitability: Eighth Army to First Army coordination scenarios
special_rules: El Alamein Veterans: +1 morale for units that fought at El Alamein
Sherman Firepower: Improved AT capability over earlier British tanks
Combined Arms Proficiency: Effective coordination between armoured and motor brigades
Adaptable: Successfully operated in both desert and hill terrain
historical_engagements: Wadi Akarit (April 6-7, 1943) - Division vs Axis defensive positions
El Kourzia (April 22-26, 1943) - Hill assault against prepared defenses
Tunisia Final Offensive (May 1943) - Exploitation and pursuit operations

source: Wikipedia - List of orders of battle for the British 1st Armoured Division (complete Tunisia OOB)
British Military History - Tunisia 1942-1943 British Armoured Divisions
Wikipedia - British First Army order of battle, 20 April 1943
Wikipedia - Raymond Briggs (British Army officer) - commander biography
Wikipedia - British armoured formations of the Second World War - 1943 establishment data
Multiple web search results confirming operations, dates, and unit assignments
TM30-410 British Army Handbook 1942 - organizational structure
British Army List April 1943 - unit rosters and assignments

exact_tank_counts.reason: Historical sources provide divisional tank establishment (186 tanks per April 1943 reorganization) and general composition (Sherman-dominated by Tunisia), but exact counts by regiment not found in available sources.
exact_tank_counts.mitigation: Used April 1943 establishment figures (186 tanks) and known transition from El Alamein mix (1 Grant, 92 Shermans, 68 Crusaders) to Sherman-dominated force. Tank counts distributed across three armoured regiments based on standard establishment.

subordinate_commanders.reason: Available sources provide division commander (Maj-Gen Raymond Briggs) but do not list brigade or regimental commanders for Tunisia Campaign period.
sources_checked: British Army List April 1943 (searched but specific commanders not found in available excerpts)
subordinate_commanders.mitigation: Division commander well documented. Subordinate commanders would require access to War Diaries or detailed regimental histories.

casualty_figures.reason: Sources describe operations and outcomes but do not provide specific casualty figures for division during Tunisia Campaign.
casualty_figures.mitigation: Not critical for TO&E extraction. Combat effectiveness assessment based on operational performance and successful outcomes.

exact_vehicle_counts.reason: Specific counts for trucks, carriers, and support vehicles not provided in available sources. Used standard British armoured division establishment for 1943.
sources_checked: British armoured formations Wikipedia article (provides personnel total: 14,964)
exact_vehicle_counts.mitigation: Based vehicle estimates on standard divisional establishment and comparison with similar 1943 British armoured divisions (7th, 10th Armoured Divisions).

11th_HAC_regiment_status.reason: Wikipedia OOB lists 11th (HAC) Regiment RHA as part of division, but April 1943 reorganization directive reduced field regiments from 3 to 2. Division may have retained 3 regiments during Tunisia or reorganized afterward.
sources_checked: British armoured formations article (mentions April 1943 reduction)
11th_HAC_regiment_status.mitigation: Included all three regiments listed in Tunisia OOB. Note added about April 1943 reorganization. Division likely retained 3 regiments during active campaign, reorganized after May 1943.

validation.notes: Strong historical documentation. Complete order of battle from Wikipedia verified against multiple sources. Division commander (Raymond Briggs) confirmed. Operations and dates well documented. Equipment transition (Crusaders/Grants to Shermans) clearly established. April 1943 reorganization (armoured division structure change) noted but implementation timing slightly uncertain. Overall excellent source base. Tier 2 (review recommended) due to estimated vehicle counts and lack of subordinate commanders, but operational history and unit composition highly reliable.
